column6: Instructions
A program is a sequence of statements. Stack a couple of 'move forward' blocks together to help me reach the goal.
A program is a sequence of statements. Stack a couple of 'move forward' blocks together to help me reach the goal.
What should I do to follow the path?
What should I do to follow the path?
Try to reach the end of this path using only two blocks.
Try to reach the end of this path using only three blocks.
Try to reach the end of this path using only two repeat blocks.
Try to reach the end of this path using only two repeat blocks.
Try to reach the end of this path using the new repeat block.
Try to reach the end of this path using only three blocks.
Reach the goal using only five blocks.
Reach the goal using only five blocks.
I will have to turn left when I cannot go straight. Use an 'if' block to see if their is a path in another direction.
I will have to turn right when I cannot go straight. Use an 'if' block to see if their is a path in another direction.
An 'if' condition will do something only if the condition is true.  Try turning right if there is a path to the right.
An 'if' condition will do something only if the condition is true.  Try turning right if there is a path to the right.
If-else blocks will do one thing or the other.
Use the 'if-else' block to help me get out of the maze!
I'm a turtle with chalk on my belly. Stack up blocks and press "Run Program" to make me draw the shown picture.
Draw a square, making each side a different color.
Make a square using only 3 blocks.  (Remember that blocks to set color are free.)
Draw a triangle whose sides are all 100 dots and are in random colors.  You'll have to figure out how far to turn.
Draw a triangle and then a square to draw an envelope.
Can you figure out how draw this triangle and square?
See if you can draw these green glasses.
After trying out these blocks, see what happens if you make them repeat 8 times.  It should look a little different every time you run it.
Figure out what number to replace the question marks with to draw a circle.
Draw anything you want. Some ideas are a stick figure, snowflake, or spiral.  You could also try out the new "set width" block.  Have fun!
Now you have learned how to draw different shapes, can you create a program that draws the house you made with tangram pieces?
Now you have learned how to draw different shapes, can you create a program that draws the square you made with two triangles?
Now you have learned how to draw different shapes, can you create a program that draws the arrow you made with tangram pieces?
Now you have learned how to draw different shapes, can you create a program that draws the ship you made with tangram pieces?
Help me flatten the field on my farm so it's ready for planting. Move me to the pile of dirt to remove it.
Move me to the hole and fill it with two shovelfuls of dirt.
Move me to the pile of dirt and tell me how many shovelfuls to remove using as few blocks as possible.
Make me remove the 4 piles.
Make me fill in all the holes. Each hole needs 5 shovelfuls of dirt.
Make me remove all the piles of dirt, using as few blocks as possible. Check out the new option in the dropdown menu on the while block.
I don't know how many shovelfuls of dirt this hole needs. Write a program that makes me fill it until it's even.
Make me fill in the hole at the end of the field, using as few blocks as possible.
Make me remove all the piles, using as few blocks as possible.
It's nighttime, and I can't tell how large the piles are. Now I don't have all the options I used to have on the while block. Move me along the field, and if there is a pile, remove it.
It's still dark outside. Move me along the field. If there is a pile, remove it, and if there is a hole, fill it in.
Find the familiar blocks in the new categories to draw a square in your favorite color.
Use the new "draw a square" block, found in the "Functions" category, to draw a small green square.
Use the "repeat" block to draw 3 squares of size 100, each 120 degrees apart, in random colors.
Now change the code to draw 36 squares, each 10 degrees apart.
Draw squares with sides of 50, 60, 70, 80, and 90 dots.  You'll need lots of blocks.
Modify this program with the "counter" block (found in the Variables category) to draw the same series of squares with fewer blocks than on the previous level.
Replace the pale (disabled) blocks with a "count with" block (in the Loops category) and "counter" block (in the Variables category) to draw the same spiral.
Draw three snowmen 150 dots tall in different colors, 100 dots apart.  Use the new "draw a snowman" function and "jump forward" block.
Use a "count with" loop to draw a family of snowmen with heights of 110, 100, 90, 80, and 70 dots, each 60 dots apart.
Draw whatever you want.  One idea is experimenting with different types of spirals.  What happens if you change the turn amount, rather than the move amount?
Try using the blocks to help me remove all the piles and fill in all the holes on the ground.
Use the new function block called "fill 5" to help me fill in this hole.
Use the function block to make me fill in all the holes.
Define a new function that removes 7 shovelfuls. Then use it to write a program that helps me remove all the piles.
Create a new function that removes 3 shovelfuls from a pile, and use it to help me level out all the piles.
Use the new functions, "fill 8" and "remove 8", to help me level out the pile and fill in the hole.
There's a cow in my field! Write a new function that helps me avoid the cow and remove the pile.
Use the function, "avoid the cow and remove 1", to help me remove all the piles.
Use one of the new functions to help me remove all of the piles on the ground with as few blocks as possible.
Move me across the field, and use the functions to help me remove all the piles and fill all the holes.

You can now see how the "draw a square" and "draw a circle" functions are defined.  Defining a function doesn't run its blocks.  You have to pull out the "draw a square" block to actually draw a square.
Using the "draw a square" function as an example, create a "draw a triangle" function and use it.
Draw triangular fences around the cats and a square fence around the cow.  Tip: Test the program as you go along.
See if you can figure out how to use "draw a square" and "draw a triangle" (and some other blocks) to draw a house around the lion.
Now create a "draw a house" function and use it house two cats.
Using "draw a square" as an example, add an input named "length" to "draw a triangle".  Then, draw triangles in different colors around the animals.
Add a "height" input to "draw a house" and build a big house for the elephant.
Here are all of the blocks from the previous level.  Modify "draw a house" so the turtle ends up at the bottom right corner of the new house.  Use this modified function to house all the animals.
You now know how to control the turtle, use loops ("repeat" and "count from"), and write and use functions.  Congratulations on becoming a programmer!
You're now free to do whatever you want.  One idea is to try running this program with different turn amounts (higher or lower than 90).  Other ideas are to draw a star, circle, heart, or animal.
